sections.title: Your Ears are Frequency Analyzers
sections.image: An illustration of the human ear. The cochlea is unraveled to look like a piano keyboard, showing how different parts of the inner ear vibrate at different frequencies.
sections.text: In the previous lesson, we looked at graphs. But graphs are for eyes, and eyes can be tricked. Your ears, however, are biological signal processors. Inside your ear is a spiral-shaped organ called the cochlea. It contains thousands of tiny hairs, and each hair is tuned to vibrate at a specific frequency.

sections.title: The Pure Tone
sections.content: When you hear a sound, your brain doesn't record the waveform over time like a tape recorder. It records which hairs are vibrating. It performs a Fourier Transform instantly.

additionalContent.text: Let's start with the simplest signal possible: The Sine Wave. In audio, we call this a 'Pure Tone'.
We will set our fundamental frequency ($f_0$) to 440Hz. In music, this is the note 'A4', the standard tuning pitch for orchestras.
additionalContent.interactive: Audio Player Interface: A simple play button labeled '440Hz Sine Wave'. Below it, a visualizer shows a smooth, single green curve oscillating gently.
additionalContent.textAfterInteractive: Listen to that. It sounds smooth, round, perhaps a bit dull. This is the sound of a single frequency with no extra ingredients. It is the vanilla ice cream of sound.

sections.title: Adding Flavor: The 3rd Harmonic
sections.content: Now, let's use the Superposition Principle. We aren't going to change the note (Pitch). We are going to change the flavor (Timbre).

additionalContent.text:
We will add a second sine wave at the **3rd Harmonic**. 

Since our fundamental is $440\text{Hz}$, the 3rd harmonic is:
$$3 \times 440\text{Hz} = 1320\text{Hz}$$
In the interactive below, slowly slide the '3rd Harmonic' slider up. Don't listen for a second note (a chord). Listen to how the *character* of the first note changes.
additionalContent.interactive: The Synthesizer Lab: A control panel. Slider 1 is fixed at 'Fundamental (440Hz)'. Slider 2 is labeled '3rd Harmonic (1320Hz)'. As the user drags Slider 2 up, a new sine wave appears on the visualizer graph, superimposed on the first, creating a slight ripple in the wave shape. The sound morphs from 'dull' to 'hollow' or 'nasal' (like a clarinet).

testYourKnowledge.question: As you increased the volume of the 3rd harmonic, what happened to the pitch (the musical note)?

options.explanation: It might feel 'brighter', but if you hum along, you are still humming the same note (A4).
Adding high frequency harmonics doesn't lower the pitch.
Correct! The fundamental frequency ($440\text{Hz}$) dictates the pitch. The harmonics only change the timbre (texture).

buildYourVocab.definition: Pronounced 'Tam-ber'. It is the 'color' or 'texture' of a sound. It is what makes a guitar sound different from a piano, even when playing the exact same note. Mathematically, Timbre is just the specific mixture of harmonic amplitudes.

sections.title: The Square Wave (Retro Gaming)
sections.content: In Lesson 1, we claimed that adding *all* odd harmonics creates a Square Wave. Let's hear the proof.

additionalContent.text: When we add the 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th harmonics, the smooth hill of the sine wave turns into a blocky, jagged wall.
additionalContent.interactive: The Synthesizer Lab (Expanded): Now features sliders for 'Fundamental', '3rd', '5th', '7th', and '9th'. A button labeled 'Square Wave Preset' automatically sets the sliders to the correct decreasing levels ($1, 1/3, 1/5, 1/7 \dots$). The visualizer shows the wave squaring off. The sound becomes harsh, buzzy, and robotic—exactly like an 8-bit NES video game.
additionalContent.textAfterInteractive: Recognize that sound? Early video games used square waves because they were easy for simple computers to generate. It sounds 'buzzy' because those sharp corners in the graph represent high-frequency energy.

stopAndThink.question: Why does a Square Wave sound 'hollow' compared to other buzzy sounds?
stopAndThink.revealText: Because it is missing half the ingredients! It completely lacks Even Harmonics ($2f, 4f, 6f$). That 'gap' in the frequency spectrum gives it a hollow, woody quality.

sections.title: Discovery Task: The Sawtooth
sections.content: Now it is your turn to be the sound engineer. We want to create a **Sawtooth Wave**. A Sawtooth wave looks like the teeth of a saw (ramping up and dropping down). It is the buzziest, richest sound in synthesis.

additionalContent.text: The Square Wave used only **Odd** harmonics. The Sawtooth wave uses **Both Even and Odd** harmonics.
Use the lab below. Try to construct a Sawtooth wave by introducing the Even harmonics ($2f, 4f, 6f$) alongside the Odd ones.
additionalContent.interactive: The Synthesizer Lab (Full): Now includes sliders for Even Harmonics (2nd, 4th, 6th) and Odd Harmonics. The visualizer updates in real-time. Students must experiment to get a sharp, ramp-like shape.
additionalContent.textAfterInteractive: Did you hear the difference? Adding the even harmonics fills in the 'hollow' gaps, creating a richer, brighter buzz. This is the sound often used for energetic synthesizer leads in electronic music.

checkYourUnderstanding.question: To convert a Square Wave into a Sawtooth Wave, what did you have to do?

options.explanation: No, that would make it sound more like a sine wave (dull).
Exactly. The Square wave was missing the 2nd, 4th, 6th, etc. Filling those in creates the Sawtooth ramp.
That would just change the pitch, not the wave shape.

sections.title: Why It Matters
sections.content: Why are we playing with synthesizers in a Computer Vision course?

additionalContent.text: Because 'Timbre' is just another word for 'Feature Extraction'.

If you want to build an AI that tells the difference between a Violin and a Flute, you can't just look at the raw waveform—it's too messy. But if you look at the **Frequency Domain** (the sliders you just played with), the answer is obvious.

whyItMatters.text: A Flute is mostly just the Fundamental ($f_0$). A Violin has a rich set of high-energy harmonics. By looking at the 'recipe' of frequencies, distinguishing objects (or sounds) becomes easy. This is exactly how we will analyze textures in images later.

sections.title: Review and Reflect
sections.image: Review Composition: A visual comparison. Left: A Flute (represented by a simple Sine Wave). Right: A Synthesizer (represented by a jagged Square Wave). Between them, an ear analyzing the incoming waves.
sections.text:
You have now heard the math. 

- A **Sine Wave** is a single frequency.
- **Timbre** (the quality of sound) is determined by which **Harmonics** are added to the fundamental.
- A **Square Wave** is created by summing **Odd Harmonics**.
- A **Sawtooth Wave** uses **All Harmonics**.

Just as we can construct any sound by mixing frequencies, we will soon learn to construct (and deconstruct) any image by mixing 2D spatial frequencies.
